;;英国内政大臣 Suella Braverman 与世纪房地产集团项目和物业管理总监 Paul Rwigamba 以及项目销售人员 Flora Uwayezu 同行2023 年 3 月 18 日在卢旺达基加利访问期间。 REUTERS/Stringer/File Photo;
;

;英国政府将于下周试图说服该国最高法院的法官推翻一项裁决，该裁决宣布其;分裂计划;将乘小船抵达卢旺达的寻求庇护者驱逐至卢旺达是非法的

;

;伦敦上诉法院;6月达成;计划，将数万名移民送往超过4,000英里（6,400公里）的东非不合法，称卢旺达不能被视为安全的第三国。

;

;周一，政府律师将在最高法院辩称这一裁决是错误的，而代表来自叙利亚、伊拉克、伊朗、越南和苏丹希望法官得出该计划本身存在缺陷的结论。

;

;苏纳克的赌注很高，因为他已将处理移民问题作为他的五个优先事项之一。成功解决这个问题可能会重振保守党的困境，因为在预计明年的选举之前，该党在民意调查中落后约 20 个百分点。

;

;“一个不兑现承诺的政府将永远无法兑现你的承诺。”受到惩罚。我们需要控制这个问题，”保守党议员布伦丹·克拉克-史密斯在本周的党年度会议上告诉路透社。

;

;苏纳克和他的部长们认为，去年启动的卢旺达计划到时任英国首相鲍里斯·约翰逊，他将粉碎人口贩运者的商业模式，并阻止人们乘坐充气船和小艇进行危险的跨海峡旅行。 2021 年 8 月，有 6 人溺水身亡，27 人在 2021 年 11 月死亡。

;

;反对者表示，这是不道德的、昂贵的，而且根本行不通。他们的成员包括人权团体、立法者（包括一些保守党人士）以及英国圣公会领袖坎特伯雷大主教。据媒体报道，就连查尔斯国王也私下表达了保留意见。

;

;该计划的命运现在掌握在五名法官手中，其中包括最高法院院长罗伯特·里德，他将开始主要听取技术性法律论证。从周一开始的三天多时间里。

;

;与欧洲许多国家一样，英国一直在努力解决如何应对逃离中东、非洲和阿富汗战区的移民涌入的问题。

;

;周二，内政部长苏埃拉·布拉弗曼 (Suella Braverman) 在向保守党成员发表的演讲中表示，一场移民“飓风”正威胁袭击英国，她发誓要制止她所谓的“虚假寻求庇护者”。

;

;移民是 2016 年脱欧公投背后的主要因素之一，英国承诺将收回对其边境的控制权。

;

;但是，尽管保守党政府承诺减少入境人数，但总体净移民数量持续上升，去年达到;历史新高; 606.00年。今年，已有超过 25,000 人乘小船抵达英国，而 2022 年发现的人数达到创纪录的 45,755 人。

;

;英国表示，其破碎的庇护系统造成了巨大损失，约有 135,000 人正在等待决定，每年超过 30 亿英镑（36 亿美元）。其中一些移民住在酒店每天的费用约为 600 万英镑。

;

;7 月通过的一项新法律现在规定内政部长有法律义务将未经许可抵达的移民驱逐回原籍国。祖国或安全的第三国。英国仅与卢旺达签署了此类协议。

;

;政府表示，将每位寻求庇护者送往这个非洲国家的平均费用为 169,000 英镑。

;

;为削减开支而采取的其他措施军事基地住房索赔者的费用遭到了强烈反对——通常来自当地保守党议员，而停泊在南海岸附近容纳数百名移民的一艘驳船在供水中发现军团菌几天后就被清空了。

;

;民意调查显示，高移民率仍然是选民的主要担忧，尽管相反也表明人们支持移民填补劳动力短缺。调查确实表明，绝大多数人认为政府在这个问题上处理得很糟糕。

;

;“如果我们减少非法移民的数量，我认为人们会在下次选举中支持我们，”克拉克-史密斯

;

;;2023-10-05T10:48:01Z;
;

;伊朗周四回击了西方对其对待妇女的批评，因为人权组织报告称一名十几岁的女孩在伊朗因未戴头巾而在德黑兰地铁与特工发生冲突，目前在医院情况危急，并处于昏迷状态。

;

;人权组织担心 16 岁的阿米塔·杰拉万德 (Armita Geravand) 可能面临与马赫萨·阿米尼 (Mahsa Amini) 相同的命运，一名 22 岁妇女去年在道德警察拘留期间昏迷死亡，引发了数月的全国抗议。

;

;德黑兰否认人权活动人士关于杰拉万德周日在与警察的对抗中受伤的报道执行该国的伊斯兰着装规范，要求女性戴头巾。

;

;外交部发言人纳赛尔·卡纳尼 (Nasser Kanaani) 批评美国、英国和德国过去一周发表的有关伊朗妇女权利的言论，以及杰拉万德的案例。

;

;“你最好关心美国、德国和英国的医护人员、患者并解决他们的处境，而不是发表干涉主义和偏见言论，并对伊朗妇女和女孩表达不真诚的担忧，”他”在X社交媒体平台上写道。

;

;美国伊朗问题副特使艾布拉姆·佩利周三在X上写道，华盛顿正在密切关注杰拉万德病情的消息。

;

;“感到震惊和担忧据报道，伊朗所谓的道德警察袭击了 16 岁的阿米塔·杰拉万德，”佩利说。

;

;“我们将继续与勇敢的伊朗人民站在一起，并与世界合作，追究该政权的责任。德国外交部长安娜莱娜·贝尔博克 (Annalena Baerbock) 在 X 上表示：“伊朗的一名年轻女性再次为自己的生命而战。就因为她在地铁里露出了头发。”

;

;两位著名的维权人士周三告诉路透社，杰拉万德在德黑兰地铁因违反头巾法与特工发生冲突后陷入昏迷。 .

;

;国家通讯社伊朗伊斯兰共和国通讯社分享的闭路电视画面显示，杰拉万德没有戴头巾，在两名女性朋友的陪同下从地铁站台走向火车。进入车厢后，其中一名女孩立即后退并手伸向地面，然后另一名女孩被乘客从机舱中拖出失去知觉。

;

;路透社无法立即验证这段视频的真实性。

;

;德黑兰地铁运营公司告诉伊朗伊斯兰通讯社闭路电视录像显示，乘客或公司员工之间没有任何言语或身体冲突的迹象。

;

;在 IRNA Geravand 发布的一段视频中，杰拉万德的父母表示，他们的女儿血压下降，失去平衡，并殴打了她走进地铁车厢。

;

;社交媒体上的人权组织敦促当局公布车厢内的视频，声称她父母的声明是在胁迫下做出的。

;

;联合国任命的人权官员上个月对伊朗新的头巾法表示担忧，该法对在公共场合不戴头巾的女性施加新的惩罚。

;

;2022 年 9 月阿米尼之死引发了持续数周的全国反政府抗议活动，伊朗多年来最严重的骚乱，并引发了当局的致命镇压。

;

;自 1979 年民众革命推翻世俗和西方支持的国王以来，伊朗神权政府对女性着装实施了限制。

;

;

;

;

;

;“支持的下降对国会的支持产生了负面影响，并最终对额外援助计划的前景产生了负面影响，”主任伊丽莎白霍夫曼说战略与国际研究中心的国会和政府事务部门。

;

;她说，更好的信息传递会有所帮助，包括让美国人明白，分配给乌克兰的大部分资金都留在美国，包括美国武器生产商的工作岗位。拜登周三表示;他将发表重要演讲; 很快就会解释为什么有必要继续帮助乌克兰。

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 18:25:04 +0800 European leaders rally around Zelenskiy at Spain summithttps://reuters.com/article/europe-summit/european-leaders-rally-around-zelenskiy-at-spain-summit-idUSKBN31507T

;在美国总统乔·拜登之后，欧洲领导人将在周四的会谈中向乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基保证他们的长期支持< a href="/world/us/white-house-says-no-specific-credible-threats-us-election-security-2022-11-07/">;表达了担心;共和党在国会的内讧可能会损害美国对基辅的援助。

;

;泽伦斯基抵达西班牙格拉纳达市参加欧洲政治共同体峰会，这是一个去年在俄罗斯入侵乌克兰后成立的论坛，旨在促进从挪威到挪威等 40 多个国家之间的合作。阿尔巴尼亚。

;

;“主要挑战是拯救欧洲的团结。不仅是欧盟，而且是整个欧洲，”泽连斯基抵达时说道，并警告俄罗斯“虚假信息攻击”。

;

;早些时候，他在社交媒体上表示，他的首要任务是加强乌克兰的防空能力。

;

;“我们将特别关注黑海地区以及加强全球粮食安全的共同努力security and freedom of navigation," he added.

;

;Russia pulled out of a deal in July that had allowed Ukraine - a leading global grain exporter - to safely ship food products out via the Black Sea.

;

;Russia has so far ;rejected UN overtures; to revive the deal, while Ukraine is continuing some exports via what it calls a temporary "humanitarian corridor" for cargo vessels.

;

;Ukraine's efforts to export grain overland via EU countries have caused a rift with Poland and some other eastern members of the bloc that are keen to protect their own farmers. Kyiv and Brussels are also discussing expanding alternative sea routes.

;

;The Granada gathering gives leaders such as French President Emmanuel Macron, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak a chance to re-state their commitment to Ukraine after political turbulence in both the US and Europe raised questions about continued support.

;

;In the US, a dispute among the Republican majority in the House of Representatives has complicated budget negotiations and prompted Democrat Biden to go from confidence that an agreement will be made on Ukraine aid to openly expressing concern.

;

;"It does worry me," Biden said on Wednesday, though he added that a majority of US lawmakers continued to support funding Ukraine.

;

;The head of the European Commission, the EU executive, Ursula von der Leyen, said on arriving in Granada that she was "very confident" that the US would continue backing Ukraine.

;

;In Europe too, support for Kyiv has recently seen setbacks.

;

;In Slovakia, former prime minister Robert Fico's party came first in a parliamentary election on pledges of halting military aid to Ukraine, while Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki has said Warsaw was no longer arming Ukraine.

;

;Some Ukrainian, European Union and NATO officials have played down these developments, saying support for Kyiv will ultimately hold steady as it is in the West's own interests.

;

;German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said on Wednesday he was "very confident" that US support for Ukraine would continue.

;

;The summit will also discuss efforts by Ukraine and others to join the EU as well as how to tackle increasing arrivals of refugees and migrants from the Middle East and Africa - both seen as existential challenges for the bloc.

;

;"Going from an EU of 27 to an EU of 35 will create many challenges internally. We will open in Granada this large debate that will take us to a deep reform of the EU," said Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez, host of the gathering.

;

;Talks on the margins of Thursday's gathering will focus on crises between ;Azerbaijan and Armenia; and between ;Serbia and Kosovo;, which have flared in recent weeks amid floundering EU efforts at mediation.

;

;Hopes for a first meeting between the leaders of Azerbaijan and Armenia since Baku's military operation last month to wrest back control of the Nagorno-Karabakh enclave were dashed when Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev decided not to attend.

;

;Many EU leaders have condemned the Azerbaijani operation, which triggered an exodus of more than 100,000 ethnic Armenians.

;

;Others, mindful that Baku increased gas supplies to the EU during an energy crunch last year, have stressed the need to focus on helping Armenia cope with the immediate humanitarian crisis, as well as providing political and economic support.

;European stocks opened higher on Thursday, after a plunge in oil prices and softer US labour data late on Wednesday helped bring US Treasury yields back down from 16-year highs.

;

;Asian shares rebounded from ;11-month lows; overnight, following gains on ;Wall Street;. China's mainland markets remain closed for holidays.

;

;US yields have been rising in recent weeks as investors reprice the chance of the US Federal Reserve keeping rates elevated for longer if inflation remains above target and the economy continues to show resilience. The 10-year US yields hit a 16-year high of 4.884% overnight .

;

;The bond sell-off paused after a cooler-than-expected ;US private payrolls report; and a ;5% drop ;in oil prices.

;

;At 0903 GMT on Thursday, the US 10-year yield was at 4.7498%.

;

;European government bond yields were mixed, with the benchmark 10-year German yield up 2 basis points at 2.961% . The German curve was its ;least inverted; since March.

;

;European stock indexes were mostly a touch higher, with the STOXX 600 up less than 0.1% on the day ;(.STOXX);.

;

;The MSCI world equity index ;(.MIWD00000PUS);, which tracks shares in 47 countries, was up 0.2%, rebounding from the previous session in which it hit its lowest since late March.

;

;Traders are now looking to US jobs data to give clues as to whether the bonds sell-off will continue. US initial jobless claims are due later on Thursday, followed by non-farm payrolls and the unemployment rate on Friday.

;

;"The question everyone's asking is: can yields continue to rise further and at what point are yields going to cause some serious damage on the economy?” said Baylee Wakefield, a portfolio manager at Aviva Investors.

;

;"If we're going to see more positive signs from non-farm payrolls on Friday then we might get investors worrying a little bit less about seeing higher interest rates going into the end of the year."

;

;Analysts said more evidence would be needed to see if the labour market was cooling. ING FX analysts cautioned in a client note that markets may be putting too much weight on Wednesday's private payrolls data.

;

;"There is a risk that the breather in bonds and the dollar correction are too reliant on expectations of a jobs data miss," ING said in a client note.

;

;In currencies, the ;US dollar index; was at 106.83 , compared to a peak earlier in the week of 107.34. The euro was steady at $1.05035 .

;

;The Japanese yen also gained relief from Wednesday's market shift, changing hands at 149 .

;

;Earlier this week, analysts ;speculated; that Japanese authorities may have intervened to support the currency, but Bank of Japan money market data showed on Wednesday that Japan most likely had not intervened.

;

;Despite the renewed strength for the US dollar, analysts still see weakness ahead, ;a Reuters poll; showed.

;

;;Oil prices;, which tanked on Wednesday, held broadly steady as the outlook for future demand remained uncertain.

;

;Gold was a touch lower at $1,819.3 .

;Zelenskiy arrived in the Spanish city of Granada for a summit of the European Political Community - a forum established last year following Russia's invasion of Ukraine to foster cooperation among more than 40 countries from Norway to Albania.

;

;"Ukraine's key priority, particularly as winter approaches, is to strengthen air defences. We have already laid the groundwork for new agreements with partners and look forward to their approval and implementation," Zelenskiy said on social media.

;

;Ukraine's efforts to export grain overland via EU countries have caused a rift with Poland and some other eastern members of the bloc that are keen to protect their own farmers. Kyiv and Brussels are also discussing expanding alternative sea routes.

;

;The Granada gathering gives leaders such as French President Emmanuel Macron, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak a chance to re-state their commitment to Ukraine after political turbulence in both the US and Europe raised questions about continued support.

;

;In the US, a dispute among the Republican majority in the House of Representatives has complicated budget negotiations and prompted Democrat Biden to go from confidence that an agreement will be made on Ukraine aid to openly expressing concern.

;

;"It does worry me," Biden said on Wednesday, before adding: "But I know there are a majority of members of the House and Senate in both parties who have said that they support funding Ukraine."

;

;Scholz said on Wednesday he was "very confident" that US support for Ukraine would continue.
